Jim Dixon wrote:
> On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Ilja Preuss wrote:
> 
>>> When you are benchmarking one thing against another, you don't give
>>> one preferential treatment.  You run them under exactly the same
>>> conditions.
> ...
>> Seriously, it depends on why you are benchmarking. When you are
>> interested in speed of long running, server side software, start-up
>> and warm-up time are quite uninteresting...
> 
> The test in question measured none of these things.  It
> measured one compute-bound activity repeated millions of
> times.  I believe that any optimizations would have occurred
> in the first few iterations.

I wouldn't be too sure about it. I once observed a long-running XSL
transformation (done with Xalan) to still become faster at the tenth
run. And the difference to the first run was in the dimension of a
factor of 100.

Anyway, what I actually wanted to say is that the meaning of "run them
under exactly the same conditions" can heavily depend on what you want
to try to measure.

>  Java programs are slowed down
> by interpretation and layers of abstraction.

And they are speeded up by runtime compilation and optimization.

> In this particular case, when asked, I said that a decent
> test would take quite some time to devise.

Yes. I didn't mean to criticize your test, just your general statement
as quoted above.

No hard feelings, Ilja
